FacilityName: Kuehne Chemical Co., Inc. - Delaware City

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
THE ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES AT YOUR FACILITY

This facility complies with applicable Chlorine Institute standards and it is our policy to adhere to applicable federal, state, and local laws.  This facility has mechanisms in place as identified in "Emergency Action Plan" to address releases of sulfur dioxide.  Designated facility personnel have received required OSHA training to respond to a sulfur dioxide release.  If an emergency were to occur (I.e. a reportable quantity release), it is our policy to notify applicable agencies and request that they provide additional response resources as needed.

A DESCRIPTION OF YOUR FACILITY AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The facility is a repackager of bulk sulfur dioxide.  A maximum of 150,000 pounds of sulfur dioxide may be on site in repackaged containers.  The sulfur dioxide storage trailer has a maximum capacity of 46,000 pounds of sulfur dioxide.  Thus, the total facility capacity is approximately 196,000 pounds of sulfur dioxide.

THE WORST-CASE AND ALTERNATIVE CASE RELEASE SCENARIOS

Our worst-case scenario is the failure of the sulfur dioxide trailer or piping when it has its maximum intended inventory of 46,000 pounds, resulting in its complete release to the environment over a period of 10 minutes.  The resulting distance to a 0.0078 mg/l sulfur dioxide toxic endpoint is 7.0 miles and public receptors are within the distance to the endpoint.  Our alternative release scenario is a 1/4" effective diameter orifice leak (representative of releases from piping failures at flanges, joints, welds, valves and valve seats and drains or bleeds that lead to an airborne release.  The resulting distance to the endpoint extends off-site to a distance of 0.2 mile.

THE GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The facility complies with EPA's accident prevention rule, applicable state and local codes and regulations.  The sulfur dioxide system is

designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with Chlorine Institute codes and standards.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

We have not had an accident involving sulfur dioxide that caused deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or shelterings in place in the five years prior to December 14, 2001.

THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

In the event of an emergency involving our sulfur dioxide system, it is our policy to employ designated facility personnel to respond to the emergency.  Designated response personnel and procedures are identified in written plans entitled "Emergency Action Plan" and "Process Safety Management Sulfur Dioxide System".  These personnel have received necessary response operations training in accordance with applicable OSHA regulations.  Designated personnel will also perform required external notifications to applicable agencies (National Response Center, State Emergency Response Comission, Local Emergency Planning Committee).

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Changes will be implemented as needed as a result of safety evaluations of the sulfur dioxide system.
